When the organism fitness evaluation is measured in minutes, and the 
overh=
ead associated with the population being distributed across 
multiple hosts=
, the questions regarding "value-added" by fitness 
evaluation are warrante=
d.

The issue addressed was simple exact duplication. The more important 
f=
undamental questions are search space coverage relative to rate of 
change =
of the fitness surface and lateral genetic mobility prior to 
pre-mature co=
mplexification.

The underlying benefit of "experience" is often expressed =
as knowing 
where not to look. Implicitly a fitness is assigned without nee=
d for 
additional evaluation. Just as the complexification process is a 
pr=
ogression implicitly intended to incorporate a refining of the 
evaluation =
tolerance of the fitness surface, the decision to evaluate 
fitness may als=
o follow a similar progression.

You don't need an electron microscope when=
 a simple "lay-of-the-land" 
will do.



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenn=
eth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> We may address it in future experime=
nts in order to speed them up, 
> but I probably would not make it the focu=
s of a publication because 
> its solution is likely fairly straightforward=
, i.e. not that deep 
in 
> a research sense. Also, the problem of revisiti=
ng the same points 
is 
> known in stochastic algorithms already.
> 
> The =
most obvious way to address the problem is simply to compare 
> new genomes=
 with what's come before.  Of course, such comparisons 
> become increasing=
ly expensive as the generations increase, and at 
> some point, it becomes =
cheaper simply to evaluate everyone rather 
> than try to figure out who is=
 a repeat.  Depending on available 
> resources, you can program it to look=
 for duplicates as long as 
it's 
> computationally advantageous.  It may t=
urn out not very useful for 
> most of the run.
> 
> There is a potential f=
or more sophisticated appraches, e.g. maybe 
> some kind of hashing scheme,=
 but they would need to promise 
> sufficiently impressive results to justi=
fy their effort.  I am not 
> sure how much effort is justified by a 10% im=
provement.  I am 
> guessing work has been done on this problem before outs=
ide of NEAT, 
> but I don't know about it offhand.
> 
> ken
>
